generated_query: Comparing the quality of life and health care utilization in patients with chronic pain and prostate enlargement

Non-bacterial chronic pelvic pain (CPP) is a type of pain that affects the lower urinary tract in men aged 50 and over, with prevalence rates ranging from 10 to 30%. It is characterised by mild to severe pain in the areas of the bladder and prostate glands, and is associated with increased fluid intake and urinary frequency. The pain is usually worse at night and can interfere with sleep, leading to further fatigue and a decrease in quality of life.

Prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) are common urological complaints in men of all ages. It is difficult to estimate the prevalence of prostatitis in the general population, but a review of medical databases and clinical studies suggests that the overall prevalence of prostatitis in men of different ages is between 20 and 30%. Prostatitis is characterized by urinary tract symptoms and signs that include pain in the pelvic area and difficulty with urination. Symptoms and signs of prostatitis vary in severity and duration, and may also be intermittent or chronic. Many patients with prostatitis have no symptoms and signs. In patients with chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) the symptoms and signs of prostatitis can be more intense and persistent. Inflammation of the prostate gland can cause urinary tract symptoms and signs in patients with prostatitis and symptoms and signs of prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) in patients with prostatitis.
